title: What happened to the Yasuo rework that Riot said they would do?
body:
They said they would rework Yasuo so that he will not be banned as much (he is currently sitting at a 28% banrate according to lolalytics, and as you know, everytime that Yasuo is even slighty strong, he is permabanned). His kit is still frustrating to play against even though he isn't considered to be unbalanced. A rework might actually allow him to be buffed, given that with his current kit, he CANNOT be buffed. Yasuo is overloaded and a rework may solve that.

Riot said a long time ago that they would do one, but they only mentioned it once, and never said a word about it again. What happened to it? Is Yasuo still considered for a rework?

impossible to land a charm on a yas dude...why even say stupid things like this. He dumpsters ahri.

Mid-dash, land it as he comes out. Land it as he auto's cannons. Land it every time he blows his windwall. It's not  much harder than on other Champs. But you have to think ahead, just like on other champs.

Any Yas worth a grain of salt knows to only Windwall either a charm or a full combo from Ahri.   Note that literally everything in Ahri's kit can be eaten by WW, so you either have him block half your kit (At which point you lose by default vs him) or he blocks the charm at the very minimum, and you can't kill him.


Ahri struggles to full 1 shot champs who just build even a smidge of defense generally, let alone champs who can full out negate a spell or more from her.

hyperbolize all you want. 

windwall has a hefty cooldown. if your charm gets walled, you can wait for it to come back up in 12 seconds. if you have cdr (you should) it will come down to 8ish. yasuo will hardly ever have cdr. 26 SECONDS. thats how long you have to trade while its down.

The Ahri vs Yasuo matchup is an exact 50-50 split on winrates, to at least the second decimal place.


This implies that it is infact a skill matchup.  Notably, I'd say that a lot of that comes down to the fact that Ahri is a far better roamer than Yasuo, and plies her power in other lanes, rather than stay and try and beat Yasuo in the 1v1s he is stronger in in this situation.

There is one very important thing to note though.  Ahri starts falling off like a rock around 30 minutes in, where Yasuo starts soaring in winrate after his large mid-game dip.   If Yasuo just survives the Ahri matchup without giving her a lead, he wins the matchup pretty much.    This is showcased in how their stats play out.  They both have about the same kill count average, yasuo on average dies once more per game than Ahri, BUT Ahri tends to get 2+ more assist than Yasuo, and Yasuo tends to have a fairly large gold lead on Ahri.   This pretty much plays to exactly how the matchup goes, where Yasuo fights to survive Ahri in lane while farming up, while Ahri tries to bully him early before roaming after he starts spiking in power and she has to leave the lane or else get bullied herself, because as much as people love to QQ about Ahri, her damage is actually fairly low for a mage/assassin.  She is great at multiple trades thanks to innate sustain, and a low CD kit, but she tends to be lackluster at all ins unless she has at least one other person helping her do damage.

Better rework Ryze

> [{quoted}](name=Shuriman God,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=hEQoWcps,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2017-09-28T12:58:38.066+0000)
>
> Better rework Ryze

Maybe Riot has finally given up, and Ryze is the new Urgot.
Explorations so far haven't been fruitful, so we have nothing pending. We still recognize the value of good Yasuo work, though.

Have you tried the public ideas yet? Things like making his Windwall appear in front of him instead of 'out of him' or limiting his dashes in some way?

I mean, internally testing them couldn't hurt, now could it?

So, Yasuo is actually ***fun*** to play against level 1-7ish. Then he backs, buys one crit item, and can just entirely ignore his kit and statcheck you to death with his autos that crit 90% of the time with one item and do absurd damage -- then it gets to be infuriating. And when he buys lifesteal and autos you for 500-600+ on top of his Q that has a 2 second CD... he just becomes a statcheck late game with hyper mobility and all kinds of survival tools and CC.

And he really has no counterplay other than him fucking up. He has an answer to every situation.

A samurai is all about precision and control, right? So, instead of autoing at the speed of light with reckless abandon, make him into a real samurai type thing. Give him some real counterplay, and lower his bullshit synergy with lifesteal and crit items.

---

So, first off, cap Yas's attack speed. I feel like 0.8-1.2ish would be fine. You could increase his base AD or something if you need to, or make extra AS give him bonus MS or something.

***Passive:*** Honestly, his passive is fine for a melee skirmisher thing. But, there needs to be one small change:

* ***His autos cannot crit***.

   * Double crit still applies to Q

***Q:*** His Q can stay the same stab thing he has, but a few changes to it: 

* First, lower the base damage. 

* Second, a passive on his Q: When Yas autos, he creates weak points on the enemy (stacking 3 times). 

   * Using his Q on an enemy with this debuff will consume the stacks to make it deal X% extra damage per stack (perhaps it could pierce 15% armor per stack as well).

***AS would still lower the CD on his Q***

***Yas does not generate stacks on his Q anymore***

***W:*** This can stay the same, but it needs to spawn ***in FRONT of Yas, not inside of him***. Just change the animation slightly and make him slash the ground in front of him or slash upwards and make a wall of wind.

* But if you're feeling nice, have it break after blocking an ultimate ability (still blocks the ability).

***E:*** This one needs some changes:

***First, make it a skillshot instead of targeted.***

* So Yas dashes in a straight line (speed and distance scaling with MS maybe), autoing everything he passes through (these autos can crit) 

   * 100% AA damage for first target struck, 80% for second, 50% for everything else 

   *If a champion is the first target struck, they gain two stacks of his auto passive thing. 

* Give it a limited number of charges, maybe 2-3, that recharges based on AS.

* Now has a ~3s CD.

***R:*** So, Yas's R is bullshit as it is currently. So let's give it more counterplay (which you supposedly like) and give Yas some clear windows of power where he's scary and feels good about what he's doing:

* New passive: When Yas lands a Q on a target with 3 stacks of his auto passive, his ult activates (one cast per 3 stack Q, does not stack).

* Yas's ult is now a two-part. First part, he dashes (not a blink) incredibly fast in a direction (after a slight delay, maybe 0.2ish seconds, the whole sheathe grab thing you know?). If he hits a champion, he throws them into the air, and deals a small amount of damage. If a champion is thrown into the air, he leaps up after them, does his thing he does now, and slams them into the ground. 

   * After casting, every auto (and first hit of E) for the next ~5s will apply three stacks of his auto passive at once.

***Has a 10s CD (on both activation and second cast) per target, but otherwise has no cooldown***

---

Now, I'm not a professional game designer, and that could very well be broken, but it preserves Yas's identity as a fast skirmisher (while enhancing the samurai feel) that relies on a lot of button mashing, combos and twitchy fingers, preserves his teamfight power (but now it's on him rather than his team stacking knockups), but adds meaningful windows of power to his kit, allows people other than himself to counterplay him, and in my opinion would make for some very high points in his gameplay that feel good, rather than just the one and done ult we have now.

So, basically you

A. Removed any real incentive to buy crit.

B. Reduced his overall damage at every stage of the game.

C. Removed the main point of being an AA based champ, while still nearly necessitating you build att spd.

D. Changed his mobility in such a way that you need to use it to go in, but then are stuck there with no real damage to back it up.

E. Made his ultimate super janky to use. To put this in context, the fastest way to get off your ultimate would be to walk up point blank to a champion, e through them (without doing e-q), auto attack them, and then hit q. As a squishy damage dealer...

F. Removed any point of picking him on a team other than windwall. In his current state, you can at least pick him to synergize with cc, or for cc by
Honestly, this gives yasuo nothing, but takes away nearly everything that people like about him. The only people that would feel good about this rework would be those who want to play against a champion who can't do anything to them.

Or to put it another way, if this rework went through, why would I want to pick this new yasuo over any other melee carry? (aside from windwall and reminiscing about old yas)

> A. Removed any real incentive to buy crit.

Q still crits, E autos can crit. You still have double crit too. So imagine your current Yas Q doing like 150% increased damage and piercing 45% armor. Now imagine if that crit.

> B. Reduced his overall damage at every stage of the game.

That's the point. He has higher windows of burst, but lower overall damage. 

> C. Removed the main point of being an AA based champ, while still nearly necessitating you build att spd.

I never thought Yas was meant to be focused around his AAs. I thought of him more like Camille -- he's focused on his abilities, and his autos, while important, aren't his identity. He's not Yi, Jax, Irelia or any of them. 

> D. Changed his mobility in such a way that you need to use it to go in, but then are stuck there with no real damage to back it up.

Wow, it's like most champs who use their mobility to go in have to go in knowing what to do and knowing they have enough damage to win. Why should Yas be any different?

> E. Made his ultimate super janky to use. To put this in context, the fastest way to get off your ultimate would be to walk up point blank to a champion, e through them (without doing e-q), auto attack them, and then hit q. As a squishy damage dealer...

These guys are all squishy, and they get right on top of people to do whatever it is they do. Yas has his passive shield, his W, and still has lifesteal and items like PD to fight with. He would by no means be incapable of getting his damage off. He just wouldn't auto win every fight he goes into like he does now if he has 1-2 kills or farm. Plus, he'd have another charge or two of his E to get out if he can't win.

> F. Removed any point of picking him on a team other than windwall. In his current state, you can at least pick him to synergize with cc, or for cc by

Why do you pick Yi? Why do you pick Fiora? He brings damage that can still hurt tanks (since he basically ignores 45% armor after he ults and his Q would hit like a truck), he's mobile, he has his W, and he would go well with a dive comp and help pick out single targets.

> Honestly, this gives yasuo nothing, but takes away nearly everything that people like about him. The only people that would feel good about this rework would be those who want to play against a champion who can't do anything to them.

It gives him counterplay (which he lacks), recenters his focus on abilities rather than autos (so Yas players can feel good about winning), gives him a more satisfying playstyle, and gives him higher damage to tanks and higher burst to squishies. Only things taken away are his limitless mobility (he'd still be absurdly mobile with this) and his ridiculous statcheck power mid game and later.

They only agreed to do so recently (in a rather passive-agressive way, it must be said) because players forced their hand with the ban spike.  Even if they genuinely intended to rework him when they said it, most likely what will happen is they'll talk about it for a bit, the ban rate will go down due to a bad mass-rework or a meta shift, and they'll decide he's not enough of a problem to put resources on and push it back indefinitely.

That was only a couple of months ago. The timetable on turning around these game elements is very long.

Riot has been saying they wanted to rework runes and masteries for years; I don't have an exact date, but I would bet you could find a Rioter comment about that as early as Season 5?

Everyone seems to forget that Rioters play this game, too. They experience all the same problems that we experience. The issue is whether or not that work is the most important work they could be doing.

Any time Riot comments on why they haven't addressed some issue, this is the response. They are working on things that are higher priority. They have a limited workforce, and it would cause other problems to expand that too quickly.

TL;DR they haven't forgotten. Just be patient while they work through their priorities list.
